node.title: ‘Simple as Water’ Review: Family Ties That Span the Globe
node.alt: Yasmin, right, with her daughter, Faten, in the documentary “Simple as Water.”
node.description: Filmed in five separate countries, this documentary follows, with ambitious scope and devastating intimacy, Syrian families displaced by war.
node.content: ["Megan Mylan\u2019s latest documentary feature takes a humble idea \u2014 telling intimate and humanizing stories of Syrian families affected by their home country\u2019s civil war \u2014 and achieves it on a nakedly ambitious scale. Filmed over five years in five separate countries, \u201cSimple as Water\u201d is anything but simple when it comes to its technical achievements, weaving together familiar immigrant narratives in ways that still manage to surprise and stun.", "The film is book ended by vignettes featuring Yasmin, a mother of four living in a refugee camp near the dockyards of Athens, who is fighting to reunite her children with their father in Germany. Her story provides an optimistic through line for Mylan\u2019s other subjects, who offer a much more devastating and uncertain look at the struggles of trying to build a new life in an unfamiliar place. In Turkey, a single mother with no time to care for her children attempts to take them to an orphanage, but her eldest son \u2014 a 12-year-old who has assumed the role of caretaker while she\u2019s at work \u2014 steadfastly refuses to go.", "In Pennsylvania, a delivery man named Omar applies for asylum for himself and his teenage brother. Through gradual reveals, we learn that Omar\u2019s brother is not only an amputee, but that he appeared on CNN as a child after his leg was blown off in a Syrian rocket strike.", "These stories avoid triteness by lingering on the daily, unassuming routines of their characters: after-school basketball games, a sunset walk through an orchard, the fashioning of a makeshift toy out of some string and a milk crate.", "The level of access that Mylan and her team receive is remarkable on a personal front as well as a political one \u2014 a segment that takes place in Syria was shot with the help of two women from Damascus who are credited under pseudonyms. It\u2019s one of the more contemplative moments in \u201cSimple as Water,\u201d bridging together Mylan\u2019s ruminations on parenthood with the uncertainty of a nation\u2019s future."]
